text: Departement Informatik Wintersession 2023 Prof. Ueli Maurer Exam Diskrete Mathematik 27. Januar 2023 Hinweise: 1.) Erlaubte Hilfsmittel: Selbstverfasste, handgeschriebene Notizen auf 6 A4-Seiten. Es ist erlaubt ein Wörterbuch zu benutzen. Es sind keine weiteren Hilfsmittel erlaubt. 2.) Falls nicht explizit ausgeschlossen dürfen Resultate (z.B. Lemmas oder Theoreme) aus dem Skript mit entsprechendem Verweis (z.B. “Lemma Skript”; die Nummer ist nicht notwending falls klar ist welches Resultat gemeint ist) ohne Beweis verwendet werden. Resultate aus der Übung dürfen nicht ohne Beweis verwendet werden. 3.) Die Aufgaben sind in drei Schwierigkeitsstufen von (⋆) bis (⋆ ⋆ ⋆) eingeteilt. 4.) Die Aufgaben sind direkt auf dem Prüfungsblatt zu lösen. Bei Platzmangel beﬁnden sich am Ende der Prüfung vier Zusatzblätter. Weitere Zusatzblätter können während der Prüfung bei uns bezogen werden. Nur von uns verteilte Zusatzblätter sind erlaubt. 5.) Die Antwortfelder unter den Aufgaben sind jeweils grosszügig bemessen. Es ist oft nicht die Erwartung, dass eine Antwort das ganze Feld füllt. 6.) Bitte verwenden Sie einen dokumentenechten Stift (also keinen Bleistift) und nicht die Farben Rot oder Grün. 7.) Bitte legen Sie die Legi für die Ausweiskontrolle auf den Tisch. 8.) Sie dürfen bis 10 Minuten vor Ende der Prüfung vorzeitig abgeben und den Raum still verlassen. 9.) Mobiltelefone und Smartwatches müssen komplett ausgeschaltet sein (kein Standby) und dürfen nicht am Körper getragen werden. Prüfungs-Nr. Sets, Relations, Functions, and Proof Patterns . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 31 Points a) Short Questions. Each correct answer gives one point. No justiﬁcation is required. (8 Points) 1.) How many elements does the set {{0, 1}, {0} × {1}} × {0} have? 2.) List each element of the set {∅, (0, 1)} × {{0} ∪ {1}, {1, 0}} exactly once. 3.) Find sets A, B, and C such that A ∩ C ̸= ∅ and A \ B ⊆ A \ C. 4.) Find a set A such that A ∩ P(A) ̸= ∅. 5.) Consider the relation ρ = {(a, b), (a, c), (b, a)} on {a, b, c}. List each element of the relation ρ3. 6.) Which of the properties reﬂexive, symmetric, antisymmetric, transitive are satisﬁed by the relation | ∪ ≡2 on N \ {0}? List all satisﬁed properties. 7.) Consider the partial order ≼ on N2 deﬁned by (a, b) ≼ (c, d) ⇐⇒ a ≤ c ∧ b ≤ d. What is the least upper bound of the set {(3, 8), (1, 4), (2, 9)}? 8.) Find a surjective function f : N → Z. b) (⋆ ⋆) Consider the set S = {1, 2, . . . , 9}. Prove that any subset A ⊆ S with |A| = 6 contains at least two distinct elements x, y ∈ A such that x + y = 10. (4 Points) Page 2 of 18 c) (⋆) Consider the relation ≼ on N2 deﬁned by (a, b) ≼ (c, d) ⇐⇒ (a, b) = (c, d) ∨ (a < c ∧ a + d ≤ b + c). Prove that ≼ is a partial order. (6 Points) Page 3 of 18 d) (⋆ ⋆) Let X and Y be two non-empty sets. Moreover, let f : X → Y and g : Y → X be functions such that f ◦ g ◦ f is injective and surjective. Prove that both f and g are injective and surjective. State clearly which assumptions and properties you use in each step. (8 Points) f is injective: f is surjective: g is injective: g is surjective: Page 4 of 18 e) (⋆ ⋆) Consider the set S = {A ⊆ N | A or N \ A is ﬁnite} . Prove or disprove that the set S is countable. (5 Points) Page 5 of 18 Task 2. Number Theory . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 11 Points a) Short Questions. Each correct answer gives one point. No justiﬁcation is required. (4 Points) 1.) Compute R2023(20222023). 2.) Compute R17(22023). 3.) Compute gcd(455, 182). 4.) Let a, b ∈ N \ {0} such that gcd(a, b) = 1. What are the possible values of gcd(3a, 7b)? b) (⋆) Alice proposes a variant of RSA encryption where e is chosen such that gcd(e, ϕ(n)) > 1. That is, the public key is (n, e) for n = pq (where p and q are distinct primes), e is chosen such that gcd(e, ϕ(n)) > 1 and the ciphertext of a message m ∈ Z∗ n is c = Rn(me). What is the problem with this variant? You do not need to prove your claim(s). (2 Points) Page 6 of 18 c) (⋆ ⋆) Prove, without using the concept of prime numbers, that for all a, b, c ∈ N \ {0} we have gcd(a, bc) | gcd(a, b) · gcd(a, c). (5 Points) Hint: For any x, y ∈ N \ {0} there exist u, v ∈ Z such that ux + vy = gcd(x, y). Page 7 of 18 Task 3. Algebra . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 25 Points a) Short Questions. Each correct answer gives the indicated number of points. No justiﬁcation is required. 1.) How many generators does the group ⟨Z29; ⊕29⟩ have? (1 Point) 2.) Let ⟨G; ·⟩ be a group and let x ∈ G be an element with order 36. What is the order of (x6, x16) in the direct product group G × G? (2 Points) 3.) Find a noncyclic group G such that all proper subgroups H of G (i.e., all subgroups H ̸= G) are cyclic. (2 Points) 4.) Consider the polynomial p(x) = x4 + 2x + 1 in the ring Z3[x]. Find all monic divisors of p(x) with degree 1. (1 Point) 5.) Compute Rx2+1(x6) in Z3[x]. (2 Points) b) (⋆) Prove that the groups ⟨Z∗ 12; ⊙12⟩ and ⟨Z4; ⊕4⟩ are not isomorphic. (3 Points) c) (⋆) Let ⟨G; +,̂, eG⟩, ⟨H; ⊙,̃, eH ⟩, and 〈J; ⊗, −1, eJ 〉 be groups. Moreover, let ϕ : G → H and φ : H → J be group homomorphisms. Prove that φ ◦ ϕ is a group homomorphism. (3 Points) Page 8 of 18 d) (⋆) Let 〈G; ·, −1, e 〉 be an abelian group. Consider the set H = {x ∈ G | ord(x) ̸= ∞}. Prove that H is a subgroup of G. (5 Points) Hint: You can use without proof that for any a ∈ G and any i, j ∈ Z we have aij = (ai)j = (aj)i. Page 9 of 18 e) (⋆ ⋆ ⋆) Let p(x) ∈ Z2[x] be an irreducible polynomial of degree 5. Consider the ﬁeld F = Z2[x]p(x). How many solutions (a, b) ∈ F × F does the equation a 2 + b 2 + ab = 0 have? (6 Points) Hint: (a − b)(a2 + b2 + ab) = a3 − b3. Page 10 of 18 Task 4. Logic . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 27 Points a) Short Questions. Each correct answer gives the indicated number of points. No justiﬁcation is required. 1.) Find a formula H which has both x and y as free variables, such that ∀xH ≡ ∀yH. (1 Point) 2.) Consider the formulas F = P (x)∧¬Q(x) and G = ∃x ¬(¬P (x) → Q(x)). Give an interpretation suitable for both formulas that is a model for F but not for G. (2 Points) 3.) Find a formula equivalent to (∀xP (x)) → (∃x Q(x) ∨ P (y)) that is in prenex form. (2 Points) b) (⋆) Use the resolution calculus to prove that the formula (A → B) → ((B → C) → (A → C)) is a tautology. You are allowed to apply multiple steps at once when transforming the formula (as long as it is easy to follow). Show your work! (5 Points) Page 11 of 18 c) (⋆) Let Π1 = (S1, P1, τ1, φ1) and Π2 = (S2, P2, τ2, φ2) be two proof systems. We combine Π1 and Π2 into a third proof system Π3 = (S1 × S2, P1 × P2, τ3, φ3), where τ3(s1, s2) = 1 def ⇐⇒ τ1(s1) ̸= τ2(s2), and φ3((s1, s2), (p1, p2)) = 1 def ⇐⇒ φ1(s1, p1) ̸= φ2(s2, p2). Prove or disprove: If Π3 is complete, then Π1 or Π2 is complete. (5 Points) Page 12 of 18 d) (⋆) Consider the calculus consisting of the following four derivation rules: {F, F → G} ⊢R1 G ∅ ⊢R2 F → (G → F ) ∅ ⊢R3 (¬F → ¬G) → (G → F ) ∅ ⊢R4 (F → G) → ((G → H) → (F → H)) Formally derive ¬A → (A → B) from ∅ in the calculus. (5 Points) Hint: You may want to instantiate R4 with F = ¬A and H = A → B. Page 13 of 18 e) (⋆ ⋆) We extend predicate logic by a new operator ♦ as follows: Syntax: If F and G are formulas, then (F ♦ G) is a formula. Semantics: A((F ♦ G)) = 1 if and only if A(F ) = 0 or A(G) = 1. Prove the following statement: For any formulas F and G we have ∀x (F ♦ G) |= (∀xF ) ♦ (∀xG). Do not use any theorems or lemmas from the lecture notes. Use the deﬁnition of |= and the semantics of predicate logic. Note that x may appear free in F , G, or both.
